attributes.title: What Darwin Never Knew
attributes.description_short: One hundred and fifty years later, scientists decode nature's greatest mysteries.
attributes.description_long: One hundred and fifty years later, scientists decode nature's greatest mysteries.

attributes.title: Lizard Kings
attributes.description_short: Meet the monitors, the largest, fiercest, and craftiest lizards on Earth.
attributes.description_long: They look like dragons and inspire visions of fire-spitting monsters. But these creatures with their long claws, razor-sharp teeth, and muscular, whip-like tails are actually monitors, the largest lizards now walking the planet. With their acute intelligence, monitors—including the largest of all, the Komodo dragon—are a very different kind of reptile.

attributes.title: Becoming Human Part 3
attributes.description_short: Last Human Standing: Many human species once shared the globe. Why do we alone remain?
attributes.description_long: NOVA examines the fate of the Neanderthals, our European cousins who died out as modern humans spread from Africa into Europe during the Ice Age. Did modern humans interbreed with Neanderthals or exterminate them? The program explores crucial evidence from the recent decoding of the Neanderthal genome.

attributes.title: Becoming Human Part 2
attributes.description_short: Birth of Humanity: New discoveries reveal how early humans hunted and formed families.
attributes.description_long: NOVA investigates the first skeleton that really looks like us–"Turkana Boy"–an astonishingly complete specimen of Homo erectus found by the famous Leakey team in Kenya. These early humans are thought to have developed key innovations that helped them thrive, including hunting large prey, the use of fire, and extensive social bonds.

attributes.title: Becoming Human Part 1
attributes.description_short: First Steps: 6 million years ago, what set our ancestors on the path from ape to human?
attributes.description_long: Part 1, "First Steps," examines the factors that caused us to split from the other great apes. The program explores the fossil of "Selam," also known as "Lucy's Child." Paleoanthropologist Zeray Alemseged spent five years carefully excavating the sandstone-embedded fossil. NOVA's cameras are there to capture the unveiling of the face, spine, and shoulder blades of this 3.3 million-year-old fossil.

attributes.title: What Are Dreams?
attributes.description_short: Psychologists and brain scientists have new answers to an age-old question.
attributes.description_long: What are dreams and why do we have them? NOVA joins leading dream researchers as they embark on a variety of neurological and psychological experiments to investigate the world of sleep and dreams.

attributes.title: Hubble's Amazing Rescue
attributes.description_short: The unlikely story about how the world's most beloved telescope was saved
attributes.description_long: The unlikely story about how the world's most beloved telescope was saved

attributes.title: Musical Minds
attributes.description_short: Oliver Saks explores how the power of music can make the brain come alive.
attributes.description_long: Oliver Saks explores how the power of music can make the brain come alive.

attributes.title: Doctors' Diaries
attributes.description_short: Seven doctors, 21 years... Saving lives is only part of the story.
attributes.description_long: In 1987, NOVA's cameras began rolling to chronicle the lives of seven young, bright medical students embarking on the longest and most rigorous endeavor in higher education: the years-long journey to become a doctor. From their first days at Harvard Medical School to the present day, none of them could have predicted what it would take, personally and professionally.

attributes.title: Megabeasts' Sudden Death
attributes.description_short: Scientists propose a radical idea of what killed off mammoths and other Ice Age animals.
attributes.description_long: Scientists propose a radical idea of what killed off mammoths and other Ice Age animals.

attributes.title: Darwin's Darkest Hour
attributes.description_short: A two-hour drama on the crisis that compelled Darwin to publish his theory of evolution
attributes.description_long: NOVA and National Geographic Television present a two-hour drama on the crisis that compelled Darwin to publish his theory of evolution.

attributes.title: Extreme Ice
attributes.description_short: An acclaimed photographer joins scientists to document the runaway melting of glaciers.
attributes.description_long: An acclaimed photographer joins scientists to document the runaway melting of glaciers.

attributes.title: Rat Attack
attributes.description_short: Why do huge swarms of rats overrun a bamboo forest in India once every half-century?
attributes.description_long: Why do huge swarms of rats overrun a bamboo forest in India once every half-century?

attributes.title: The Spy Factory
attributes.description_short: Examine the high-tech eavesdropping carried out by the National Security Agency.
attributes.description_long: Examine the high-tech eavesdropping carried out by the National Security Agency and the pitfalls of surveillance in an age of terrorism.

attributes.title: The Incredible Journey of the Butterflies
attributes.title_sortable: The Incredible Journey of the Butterflies
attributes.description_short: Follow the 2,000-mile migration of monarchs to a sanctuary in the highlands of Mexico.
attributes.description_long: Follow the 2,000-mile migration of monarchs to a sanctuary in the highlands of Mexico.
